label: Operation
definitions: A function that processes a set of inputs and results in a set of outputs, or associates arguments (inputs) with values (outputs).

Special cases are: a) An operation that consumes no input (has no input arguments). Such operation is either a constant function, or an operation depending only on the underlying state. b) An operation that may modify the underlying state but has no output. c) The singular-case operation with no input or output, that still may modify the underlying state.

label: Query and retrieval
definitions: Search or query a data resource and retrieve entries and / or annotation.

label: Annotation
definitions: Annotate an entity (typically a biological or biomedical database entity) with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
This is a broad concept and is used a placeholder for other, more specific concepts.

label: Indexing
definitions: Generate an index of (typically a file of) biological data.

label: Sequence generation
definitions: Generate a molecular sequence by some means.

label: Sequence editing
definitions: Edit or change a molecular sequence, either randomly or specifically.

label: Sequence merging
definitions: Merge two or more (typically overlapping) molecular sequences.

label: Sequence conversion
definitions: Convert a molecular sequence from one type to another.

label: Sequence complexity calculation
definitions: Calculate sequence complexity, for example to find low-complexity regions in sequences.

label: Sequence ambiguity calculation
definitions: Calculate sequence ambiguity, for example identity regions in protein or nucleotide sequences with many ambiguity codes.

label: Sequence composition calculation
definitions: Calculate character or word composition or frequency of a molecular sequence.

label: Repeat sequence analysis
definitions: Find and/or analyse repeat sequences in (typically nucleotide) sequences.

Repeat sequences include tandem repeats, inverted or palindromic repeats, DNA microsatellites (Simple Sequence Repeats or SSRs), interspersed repeats, maximal duplications and reverse, complemented and reverse complemented repeats etc. Repeat units can be exact or imperfect, in tandem or dispersed, of specified or unspecified length.

label: Sequence motif discovery
definitions: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).
Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).

label: Sequence motif recognition
definitions: Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).

label: Sequence motif comparison
definitions: Find motifs shared by molecular sequences.

label: Protein flexibility and motion analysis
definitions: Analyse flexibility and motion in protein structure.

Use this concept for analysis of flexible and rigid residues, local chain deformability, regions undergoing conformational change, molecular vibrations or fluctuational dynamics, domain motions or other large-scale structural transitions in a protein structure.

label: Protein structural motif recognition
definitions: Identify or screen for 3D structural motifs in protein structure(s).

This includes conserved substructures and conserved geometry, such as spatial arrangement of secondary structure or protein backbone. Methods might use structure alignment, structural templates, searches for similar electrostatic potential and molecular surface shape, surface-mapping of phylogenetic information etc.

label: Protein domain recognition
definitions: Identify structural domains in a protein structure from first principles (for example calculations on structural compactness).

label: Protein architecture analysis
definitions: Analyse the architecture (spatial arrangement of secondary structure) of protein structure(s).

label: Residue interaction calculation
definitions: Calculate or extract inter-atomic, inter-residue or residue-atom contacts, distances and interactions in protein structure(s).

label: Protein geometry calculation
definitions: Calculate, visualise or analyse phi/psi angles of a protein structure.

label: Protein property calculation
definitions: Extract, calculate or predict non-positional (physical or chemical) properties of a protein, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence, from processing a protein sequence or 3D structure.

This includes methods to render and visualise the properties of a protein sequence, and a residue-level search for properties such as solvent accessibility, hydropathy, secondary structure, ligand-binding etc.

label: Peptide immunogenicity prediction
definitions: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.
This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.
This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.

label: Sequence feature detection
definitions: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.
Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.

label: Sequence feature comparison
definitions: Compare the feature tables of two or more molecular sequences.

label: Sequence alignment analysis
definitions: Analyse a molecular sequence alignment.

label: Sequence alignment comparison
definitions: Compare (typically by aligning) two molecular sequence alignments.
See also 'Sequence profile alignment'.

label: Sequence alignment conversion
definitions: Convert a molecular sequence alignment from one type to another (for example amino acid to coding nucleotide sequence).

label: Nucleic acid property calculation
definitions: Calculate or predict physical or chemical properties of nucleic acid molecules, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence.

label: Splice transcript prediction
definitions: Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.

label: Frameshift detection
definitions: Detect frameshifts in DNA sequences, including frameshift sites and signals, and frameshift errors from sequencing projects.
Methods include sequence alignment (if related sequences are available) and word-based sequence comparison.

label: Vector sequence detection
definitions: Detect vector sequences in nucleotide sequence, typically by comparison to a set of known vector sequences.

label: Protein secondary structure prediction
definitions: Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.

Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.

label: Protein super-secondary structure prediction
definitions: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).
Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.

label: Transmembrane protein prediction
definitions: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.

label: Transmembrane protein analysis
definitions: Analyse transmembrane protein(s), typically by processing sequence and / or structural data, and write an informative report for example about the protein and its transmembrane domains / regions.

Use this (or child) concept for analysis of transmembrane domains (buried and exposed faces), transmembrane helices, helix topology, orientation, inter-helical contacts, membrane dipping (re-entrant) loops and other secondary structure etc. Methods might use pattern discovery, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment, structural profiles, amino acid property analysis, comparison to known domains or some combination (hybrid methods).

label: Residue interaction prediction
definitions: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.
Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.

label: Protein interaction network analysis
definitions: Analyse a network of protein interactions.

label: Pathway or network comparison
definitions: Compare two or more biological pathways or networks.

label: RNA secondary structure prediction
definitions: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).

label: Nucleic acid folding analysis
definitions: Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.

label: Genetic mapping
definitions: Generate a genetic (linkage) map of a DNA sequence (typically a chromosome) showing the relative positions of genetic markers based on estimation of non-physical distances.

Mapping involves ordering genetic loci along a chromosome and estimating the physical distance between loci. A genetic map shows the relative (not physical) position of known genes and genetic markers.
This includes mapping of the genetic architecture of dynamic complex traits (functional mapping), e.g. by characterisation of the underlying quantitative trait loci (QTLs) or nucleotides (QTNs).

label: Linkage analysis
definitions: Analyse genetic linkage.

For example, estimate how close two genes are on a chromosome by calculating how often they are transmitted together to an offspring, ascertain whether two genes are linked and parental linkage, calculate linkage map distance etc.

label: Codon usage table generation
definitions: Calculate codon usage statistics and create a codon usage table.

label: Codon usage table comparison
definitions: Compare two or more codon usage tables.

label: Codon usage analysis
definitions: Process (read and / or write) codon usage data, e.g. analyse codon usage tables or codon usage in molecular sequences.

label: Base position variability plotting
definitions: Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.

label: Sequence word comparison
definitions: Find exact character or word matches between molecular sequences without full sequence alignment.

label: Sequence distance matrix generation
definitions: Calculate a sequence distance matrix or otherwise estimate genetic distances between molecular sequences.

label: Sequence redundancy removal
definitions: Compare two or more molecular sequences, identify and remove redundant sequences based on some criteria.

label: Sequence clustering
definitions: Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.

label: Sequence alignment
definitions: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.

label: Structure-based sequence alignment
definitions: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.

label: Structure alignment
definitions: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.

label: Sequence profile generation
definitions: Generate some type of sequence profile (for example a hidden Markov model) from a sequence alignment.

label: 3D profile generation
definitions: Generate some type of structural (3D) profile or template from a structure or structure alignment.

label: Sequence profile alignment
definitions: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.
A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

label: Protein threading
definitions: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

label: Protein fold recognition
definitions: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.

Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.

label: Literature search
definitions: Query scientific literature, in search for articles, article data, concepts, named entities, or for statistics.

label: Text mining
definitions: Process and analyse text (typically scientific literature) to extract information from it.

label: Virtual PCR
definitions: Perform in-silico (virtual) PCR.

label: PCR primer design
synonyms: PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)
PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)
PCR primer design (based on gene structure)
definitions: Design or predict oligonucleotide primers for PCR and DNA amplification etc.

Primer design involves predicting or selecting primers that are specific to a provided PCR template. Primers can be designed with certain properties such as size of product desired, primer size etc. The output might be a minimal or overlapping primer set.

This includes predicting primers based on gene structure, promoters, exon-exon junctions, predicting primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species, primers for for gene transcription profiling,  for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs),  for large scale sequencing, or for methylation PCRs.

label: Microarray probe design
definitions: Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.

label: Sequence assembly
definitions: Combine (align and merge) overlapping fragments of a DNA sequence to reconstruct the original sequence.

For example, assemble overlapping reads from paired-end sequencers into contigs (a contiguous sequence corresponding to read overlaps). Or assemble contigs, for example ESTs and genomic DNA fragments, depending on the detected fragment overlaps.

label: Gene expression clustering
definitions: Perform cluster analysis of gene expression data to identify groups with similar gene-expression profiles, for example by clustering.

label: Gene expression profiling
definitions: The measurement of the gene expression of multiple genes in a cell, tissue, sample etc., in order to get an impression of biological function.
Metagenomic inference is the profiling of phylogenetic marker genes in order to predict metagenome function.
Gene expression profiling generates some sort of gene expression profile, for example from microarray data.

label: Gene expression comparison
definitions: Comparison of gene expression profiles.

label: Protein secondary structure assignment
definitions: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.

label: Protein structure assignment
definitions: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.

label: Protein model validation
definitions: Evaluate the quality or correctness a protein three-dimensional model.

This includes methods that calculate poor quality residues. The scoring function to identify poor quality residues may consider residues with bad atoms or atoms with high B-factor, residues in the N- or C-terminal position, adjacent to an unstructured residue, non-canonical residues, glycine and proline (or adjacent to these such residues).

Model validation might involve checks for atomic packing, steric clashes (bumps), volume irregularities, agreement with electron density maps, number of amino acid residues, percentage of residues with missing or bad atoms, irregular Ramachandran Z-scores, irregular Chi-1 / Chi-2 normality scores, RMS-Z score on bonds and angles etc.

The PDB file format has had difficulties, inconsistencies and errors. Corrections can include identifying a meaningful sequence, removal of alternate atoms, correction of nomenclature problems, removal of incomplete residues and spurious waters, addition or removal of water, modelling of missing side chains, optimisation of cysteine bonds, regularisation of bond lengths, bond angles and planarities etc.

label: Molecular model refinement
definitions: Refine (after evaluation) a model of a molecular structure (typically a protein structure) to reduce steric clashes, volume irregularities etc.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic tree.
Phylogenetic trees are usually constructed from a set of sequences from which an alignment (or data matrix) is calculated.

label: Phylogenetic tree analysis
definitions: Analyse an existing phylogenetic tree or trees, typically to detect features or make predictions.

label: Phylogenetic tree comparison
definitions: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees.
For example, to produce a consensus tree, subtrees, supertrees, calculate distances between trees or test topological similarity between trees (e.g. a congruence index) etc.

label: Phylogenetic tree editing
definitions: Edit a phylogenetic tree.

label: Phylogenetic footprinting / shadowing
definitions: Infer a phylogenetic tree by comparing orthologous sequences in different species, particularly many closely related species (phylogenetic shadowing).

A phylogenetic 'shadow' represents the additive differences between individual sequences. By masking or 'shadowing' variable positions a conserved sequence is produced with few or none of the variations, which is then compared to the sequences of interest to identify significant regions of conservation.

label: Protein modelling (mutation)
definitions: Predict the effect of point mutation on a protein structure, in terms of strucural effects and protein folding, stability and function.

This includes 1) rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.  2) Protein SNP mapping, which maps and modesl the effects of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on protein structure(s).  Methods might predict silent or pathological mutations.

label: Enzyme kinetics calculation
definitions: Calculate Km, Vmax and derived data for an enzyme reaction.

label: Formatting
definitions: Reformat a file of data (or equivalent entity in memory).

label: Format validation
definitions: Test and validate the format and content of a data file.

label: Visualisation
definitions: Visualise, plot or render (graphically) biomolecular data such as molecular sequences or structures.

label: Sequence database search
definitions:
Search a sequence database by sequence comparison and retrieve similar sequences.
sequences matching a given sequence motif or pattern, such as a Prosite pattern or regular expression.
This excludes direct retrieval methods (e.g. the dbfetch program).

label: Structure database search
definitions: Search a tertiary structure database, typically by sequence and/or structure comparison, or some other means, and retrieve structures and associated data.

label: Sequence similarity search
definitions: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.

label: Sequence database search (by property)
definitions: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences with a specified property, typically a physicochemical or compositional property.

label: Structural similarity search
definitions: Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.

label: Sequence annotation
definitions: Annotate a molecular sequence record with terms from a controlled vocabulary.

label: Genome annotation
definitions: Annotate a genome sequence with terms from a controlled vocabulary.

label: Nucleic acid sequence reverse and complement
definitions: Generate the reverse and / or complement of a nucleotide sequence.

label: Random sequence generation
definitions: Generate a random sequence, for example, with a specific character composition.

label: Nucleic acid restriction digest
definitions: Generate digest fragments for a nucleotide sequence containing restriction sites.

label: Protein sequence cleavage
definitions: Cleave a protein sequence into peptide fragments (corresponding to enzymatic or chemical cleavage).

label: Sequence mutation and randomisation
definitions: Mutate a molecular sequence a specified amount or shuffle it to produce a randomised sequence with the same overall composition.

label: Sequence masking
definitions: Mask characters in a molecular sequence (replacing those characters with a mask character).
For example, SNPs or repeats in a DNA sequence might be masked.

label: Sequence cutting
definitions: Cut (remove) characters or a region from a molecular sequence.

label: Restriction site creation
definitions: Create (or remove) restriction sites in sequences, for example using silent mutations.

label: DNA translation
definitions: Translate a DNA sequence into protein.

label: DNA transcription
definitions: Transcribe a nucleotide sequence into mRNA sequence(s).

label: Repeat sequence detection
definitions: Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.

label: Repeat sequence organisation analysis
definitions: Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.

label: Accessible surface calculation
definitions: Calculate solvent accessible or buried surface areas in protein or other molecular structures.
Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).

label: Protein dipole moment calculation
definitions: Calculate whether a protein structure has an unusually large net charge (dipole moment).

label: Molecular surface calculation
definitions: Calculate the molecular surface area in proteins and other macromolecules.

label: Protein-nucleic acid binding site analysis
definitions: Analyse RNA or DNA-binding sites in protein structure.

label: Protein peeling
definitions: Decompose a structure into compact or globular fragments (protein peeling).

label: Protein distance matrix calculation
definitions: Calculate a matrix of distance between residues (for example the C-alpha atoms) in a protein structure.

label: Protein contact map calculation
definitions: Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.

label: Residue cluster calculation
definitions: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.
This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.

label: Hydrogen bond calculation
definitions: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acids and other groups.
The output might include the atoms involved in the bond, bond geometric parameters and bond enthalpy.

label: Ramachandran plot calculation
definitions: Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

label: Ramachandran plot validation
definitions: Validate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

label: Protein molecular weight calculation
definitions: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein sequence or fragments.

label: Protein extinction coefficient calculation
definitions: Predict extinction coefficients or optical density of a protein sequence.

label: Protein pKa calculation
definitions: Calculate pH-dependent properties from pKa calculations of a protein sequence.

label: Protein titration curve plotting
definitions: Plot a protein titration curve.

label: Protein isoelectric point calculation
definitions: Calculate isoelectric point of a protein sequence.

label: Protein hydrogen exchange rate calculation
definitions: Estimate hydrogen exchange rate of a protein sequence.

label: Protein hydrophobic region calculation
definitions: Calculate hydrophobic or hydrophilic / charged regions of a protein sequence.

label: Protein aliphatic index calculation
definitions: Calculate aliphatic index (relative volume occupied by aliphatic side chains) of a protein.

label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting
definitions: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.
Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.

label: Protein globularity prediction
definitions: Predict the stability or globularity of a protein sequence, whether it is intrinsically unfolded etc.

label: Protein solubility prediction
definitions: Predict the solubility or atomic solvation energy of a protein sequence.

label: Protein crystallizability prediction
definitions: Predict crystallizability of a protein sequence.

label: Nucleic acid feature detection
definitions: Predict, recognise and identify features in nucleotide sequences such as functional sites or regions, typically by scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.
Methods typically involve scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.

label: Epitope mapping
definitions: Predict antigenic determinant sites (epitopes) in protein sequences.
Epitope mapping is commonly done during vaccine design.

label: Post-translation modification site prediction
definitions: Predict post-translation modification sites in protein sequences.

Methods might predict sites of methylation, N-terminal myristoylation, N-terminal acetylation, sumoylation, palmitoylation, phosphorylation, sulfation, glycosylation, glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) modification sites (GPI lipid anchor signals) etc.

label: Protein signal peptide detection
definitions: Detect or predict signal peptides and signal peptide cleavage sites in protein sequences.
Methods might use sequence motifs and features, amino acid composition, profiles, machine-learned classifiers, etc.

label: Protein-nucleic acid binding prediction
definitions: Predict RNA and DNA-binding binding sites in protein sequences.
This includes methods that predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).

label: Protein cleavage site prediction
definitions: Detect or predict cleavage sites (enzymatic or chemical) in protein sequences.

label: Transposon prediction
definitions: Detect or predict transposons, retrotransposons / retrotransposition signatures etc.

label: PolyA signal detection
definitions: Detect polyA signals in nucleotide sequences.

label: Quadruplex formation site detection
definitions: Detect quadruplex-forming motifs in nucleotide sequences.
Quadruplex (4-stranded) structures are formed by guanine-rich regions and are implicated in various important biological processes and as therapeutic targets.

label: CpG island and isochore detection
definitions: Find CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence or isochores in genome sequences.

An isochore is long region (> 3 KB) of DNA with very uniform GC content, in contrast to the rest of the genome. Isochores tend tends to have more genes, higher local melting or denaturation temperatures, and different flexibility. Methods might calculate fractional GC content or variation of GC content, predict methylation status of CpG islands etc. This includes methods that visualise CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence, for example plot isochores in a genome sequence.

label: Restriction site recognition
definitions: Find and identify restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in (typically) DNA sequences, for example to generate a restriction map.

label: Nucleosome formation or exclusion sequence prediction
definitions: Identify or predict nucleosome exclusion sequences (nucleosome free regions) in DNA.

label: Splice site prediction
definitions: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.
Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.

label: Operon prediction
definitions: Find operons (operators, promoters and genes) in bacteria genes.

label: Coding region prediction
definitions: Predict protein-coding regions (CDS or exon) or open reading frames in nucleotide sequences.

label: SECIS element prediction
definitions: Predict selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in a DNA sequence.
SECIS elements are around 60 nucleotides in length with a stem-loop structure directs the cell to translate UGA codons as selenocysteines.

label: Transcriptional regulatory element prediction
definitions: Identify or predict transcriptional regulatory motifs, patterns, elements or regions in DNA sequences.

This includes promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators, regulatory protein or transcription factor binding sites etc. Methods might be specific to a particular genome and use motifs, word-based / grammatical methods, position-specific frequency matrices, discriminative pattern analysis etc.

label: Translation initiation site prediction
definitions: Predict translation initiation sites, possibly by searching a database of sites.

label: Promoter prediction
definitions: Identify or predict whole promoters or promoter elements (transcription start sites, RNA polymerase binding site, transcription factor binding sites, promoter enhancers etc) in DNA sequences.
Methods might recognize CG content, CpG islands, splice sites, polyA signals etc.

label: cis-regulatory element prediction
definitions: Identify, predict or analyse cis-regulatory elements  in DNA sequences (TATA box, Pribnow box, SOS box, CAAT box, CCAAT box, operator etc.) or in RNA sequences (e.g. riboswitches).

Cis-regulatory elements (cis-elements) regulate the expression of genes located on the same strand from which the element was transcribed. Cis-elements are found in the 5' promoter region of the gene, in an intron, or in the 3' untranslated region. Cis-elements are often binding sites of one or more trans-acting factors. They also occur in RNA sequences, e.g. a riboswitch is a region of an mRNA molecule that bind a small target molecule that regulates the gene's activity.

label: trans-regulatory element prediction
definitions: Identify or predict functional RNA sequences with a gene regulatory role (trans-regulatory elements) or targets.
Trans-regulatory elements regulate genes distant from the gene from which they were transcribed.

label: S/MAR prediction
definitions: Identify matrix/scaffold attachment regions (MARs/SARs) in DNA sequences.
MAR/SAR sites often flank a gene or gene cluster and are found nearby cis-regulatory sequences. They might contribute to transcription regulation.

label: Transcription factor binding site prediction
definitions: Identify or predict transcription factor binding sites in DNA sequences.

label: Exonic splicing enhancer prediction
definitions: Identify or predict exonic splicing enhancers (ESE) in exons.
An exonic splicing enhancer (ESE) is 6-base DNA sequence motif in an exon that enhances or directs splicing of pre-mRNA or hetero-nuclear RNA (hnRNA) into mRNA.

label: Sequence alignment validation
definitions: Evaluate molecular sequence alignment accuracy.
Evaluation might be purely sequence-based or use structural information.

label: Sequence alignment analysis (conservation)
definitions: Analyse character conservation in a molecular sequence alignment, for example to derive a consensus sequence.

Use this concept for methods that calculate substitution rates, estimate relative site variability, identify sites with biased properties, derive a consensus sequence, or identify highly conserved or very poorly conserved sites, regions, blocks etc.

label: Sequence alignment analysis (site correlation)
definitions: Analyse correlations between sites in a molecular sequence alignment.
This is typically done to identify possible covarying positions and predict contacts or structural constraints in protein structures.

label: Chimera detection
definitions: Detects chimeric sequences (chimeras) from a sequence alignment.

A chimera includes regions from two or more phylogenetically distinct sequences. They are usually artifacts of PCR and are thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to another DNA strand and is subsequently copied to completion in later PCR cycles.

label: Recombination detection
definitions: Detect recombination (hotspots and coldspots) and identify recombination breakpoints in a sequence alignment.
Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.

label: Indel detection
definitions: Identify insertion, deletion and duplication events from a sequence alignment.
Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.

label: Nucleic acid thermodynamic property calculation
definitions: Calculate a thermodynamic property of DNA or DNA/RNA, such as melting temperature, enthalpy and entropy.

label: Nucleic acid melting profile plotting
definitions: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting profile.
A melting profile is used to visualise and analyse partly melted DNA conformations.

label: Nucleic acid stitch profile plotting
definitions: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA stitch profile.
A stitch profile represents the alternative conformations that partly melted DNA can adopt in a temperature range.

label: Nucleic acid melting curve plotting
definitions: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting curve.

label: Nucleic acid probability profile plotting
definitions: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA probability profile.

label: Nucleic acid temperature profile plotting
definitions: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.

label: Nucleic acid curvature calculation
definitions: Calculate curvature and flexibility / stiffness of a nucleotide sequence.
This includes properties such as.

label: microRNA detection
definitions: Identify or predict microRNA sequences (miRNA) and precursors or microRNA targets / binding sites in a DNA sequence.

label: tRNA gene prediction
definitions: Identify or predict tRNA genes in genomic sequences (tRNA).

label: siRNA binding specificity prediction
definitions: Assess binding specificity of putative siRNA sequence(s), for example for a functional assay, typically with respect to designing specific siRNA sequences.

label: Protein secondary structure prediction (helices)
definitions: Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.

label: Protein secondary structure prediction (turns)
definitions: Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.

label: Protein secondary structure prediction (coils)
definitions: Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.

label: Disulfide bond prediction
definitions: Predict cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein sequences.

label: Protein structure prediction
definitions: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.

label: Nucleic acid structure prediction
definitions: Predict structure of DNA or RNA.
Methods might identify thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures.

label: Ab initio structure prediction
definitions: Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.

label: Protein modelling
definitions: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.

The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.

label: Molecular docking
definitions: Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.

This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.

label: Protein modelling (backbone)
definitions: Model protein backbone conformation.
Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.

label: Protein modelling (side chains)
definitions: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

label: Protein modelling (loops)
definitions: Model loop conformation in protein structures.

label: Protein-ligand docking
definitions: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

label: Structured RNA prediction and optimisation
definitions: Predict or optimise RNA sequences (sequence pools) with likely secondary and tertiary structure for in vitro selection.

label: SNP detection
definitions: Find single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) - single nucleotide change in base positions - between sequences. Typically done for sequences from a high-throughput sequencing experiment that differ from a reference genome and which might, especially by reference to population frequency or functional data, indicate a polymorphism.
This includes functional SNPs for large-scale genotyping purposes, disease-associated non-synonymous SNPs etc.

label: Radiation Hybrid Mapping
definitions: Generate a physical (radiation hybrid) map of genetic markers in a DNA sequence using provided radiation hybrid (RH) scores for one or more markers.

label: Haplotype mapping
definitions: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.

Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. Haplotype comparison is a useful way to characterize the genetic variation between individuals. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. Tools might use combinatorial functions (for example parsimony) or a likelihood function or model with optimisation such as minimum error correction (MEC) model, expectation-maximisation algorithm (EM), genetic algorithm or Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).

label: Linkage disequilibrium calculation
definitions: Calculate linkage disequilibrium; the non-random association of alleles or polymorphisms at two or more loci (not necessarily on the same chromosome).
Linkage disequilibrium is identified where a combination of alleles (or genetic markers) occurs more or less frequently in a population than expected by chance formation of haplotypes.

label: Genetic code prediction
definitions: Predict genetic code from analysis of codon usage data.

label: Dot plot plotting
definitions: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.

label: Pairwise sequence alignment
definitions: Align exactly two molecular sequences.
Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

label: Multiple sequence alignment
definitions: Align more than two molecular sequences.
This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.

label: Local alignment
definitions: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.
Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.

label: Global alignment
definitions: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.
Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.

label: Tree-based sequence alignment
synonyms: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
definitions: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.

label: RNA secondary structure alignment
definitions: Align RNA secondary structures.

label: Pairwise structure alignment
definitions: Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.

label: Multiple structure alignment
definitions: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
This includes methods that use an existing alignment.

label: Local structure alignment
definitions: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.

label: Global structure alignment
definitions: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.

label: Mapping assembly
definitions: Sequence assembly by combining fragments using an existing backbone sequence, typically a reference genome.
The final sequence will resemble the backbone sequence. Mapping assemblers are usually much faster and less memory intensive than de-novo assemblers.

label: De-novo assembly
definitions: Sequence assembly by combining fragments without the aid of a reference sequence or genome.
De-novo assemblers are much slower and more memory intensive than mapping assemblers.

label: Genome assembly
definitions: The process of assembling many short DNA sequences together such thay they represent the original chromosomes from which the DNA originated.

label: EST assembly
definitions: Sequence assembly for EST sequences (transcribed mRNA).
Assemblers must handle (or be complicated by) alternative splicing, trans-splicing, single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), recoding, and post-transcriptional modification.

label: Sequence tag mapping
definitions: Make sequence tag to gene assignments (tag mapping) of SAGE, MPSS and SBS data.
Sequence tag mapping assigns experimentally obtained sequence tags to known transcripts or annotate potential virtual sequence tags in a genome.

label: Heat map generation
definitions: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.
The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.

label: Gene to pathway mapping
definitions: Map a gene expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (data centric)
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic tree from a specific type of data.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (method centric)
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic tree using a specific method.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from molecular sequences)
definitions: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.
Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from continuous quantitative characters)
synonyms: Phylogenetic tree construction (from continuous quantitative characters)
definitions: Phylogenetic tree construction from continuous quantitative character data.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from gene frequencies)
definitions: Phylogenetic tree construction from gene frequency data.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from polymorphism data)
definitions: Phylogenetic tree construction from polymorphism data including microsatellites, RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), RAPD (random-amplified polymorphic DNA) and AFLP (amplified fragment length polymorphisms) data.

label: Phylogenetic species tree construction
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic species tree, for example, from a genome-wide sequence comparison.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (parsimony methods)
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing a sequence alignment and searching for the tree with the fewest number of character-state changes from the alignment.
This includes evolutionary parsimony (invariants) methods.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (minimum distance methods)
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing (or using precomputed) distances between sequences and searching for the tree with minimal discrepancies between pairwise distances.
This includes neighbor joining (NJ) clustering method.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
synonyms: Phylogenetic tree construction (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic tree by relating sequence data to a hypothetical tree topology using a model of sequence evolution.

Maximum likelihood methods search for a tree that maximizes a likelihood function, i.e. that is most likely given the data and model. Bayesian analysis estimate the probability of tree for branch lengths and topology, typically using a Monte Carlo algorithm.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (quartet methods)
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing four-taxon trees (4-trees) and searching for the phylogeny that matches most closely.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (AI methods)
definitions: Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.

label: DNA substitution modelling
definitions: Identify a plausible model of DNA substitution that explains a molecular (DNA or protein) sequence alignment.

label: Phylogenetic tree analysis (shape)
definitions: Analyse the shape (topology) of a phylogenetic tree.

label: Phylogenetic tree bootstrapping
definitions: Apply bootstrapping or other measures to estimate confidence of a phylogenetic tree.

label: Phylogenetic tree analysis (gene family prediction)
definitions: Predict families of genes and gene function based on their position in a phylogenetic tree.

label: Phylogenetic tree analysis (natural selection)
definitions: Analyse a phylogenetic tree to identify allele frequency distribution and change that is subject to evolutionary pressures (natural selection, genetic drift, mutation and gene flow). Identify type of natural selection (such as stabilizing, balancing or disruptive).

Stabilizing/purifying (directional) selection favors a single phenotype and tends to decrease genetic diversity as a population stabilizes on a particular trait, selecting out trait extremes or deleterious mutations. In contrast, balancing selection maintain genetic polymorphisms (or multiple alleles), whereas disruptive (or diversifying) selection favors individuals at both extremes of a trait.

label: Phylogenetic tree generation (consensus)
definitions: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.
Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.

label: Phylogenetic sub/super tree detection
definitions: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to detect subtrees or supertrees.

label: Phylogenetic tree distances calculation
definitions: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to calculate distances between trees.

label: Phylogenetic tree annotation
definitions: Annotate a phylogenetic tree with terms from a controlled vocabulary.

label: DNA vaccine design
definitions: Predict or optimise DNA to elicit (via DNA vaccination) an immunological response.

label: Sequence visualisation
definitions: Visualise, format or render a molecular sequence or sequences such as a sequence alignment, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.

label: Sequence cluster visualisation
definitions: Visualise, format or render sequence clusters.

label: Phylogenetic tree visualisation
definitions: Render or visualise a phylogenetic tree.

label: Structure visualisation
definitions: Visualise or render molecular structure, for example a high-quality static picture or animation.  This includes secondary structure such as knots, pseudoknots etc. as well as tertiary and quaternary structure.

label: Expression data visualisation
definitions: Visualise microarray or other expression data.

label: Map drawing
definitions: Draw or visualise a DNA map.

label: Restriction map drawing
definitions: Draw or visualise restriction maps in DNA sequences.

label: Plasmid map drawing
definitions: Draw a circular maps of DNA, for example a plasmid map.

label: Operon drawing
definitions: Visualise operon structure etc.

label: Protein function prediction
definitions: Predict general functional properties of a protein.
For functional properties that can be mapped to a sequence, use 'Sequence feature detection (protein)' instead.

label: Protein function comparison
definitions: Compare the functional properties of two or more proteins.

label: Gene regulatory network analysis
definitions: Analyse a known network of gene regulation.

label: Loading
definitions: Prepare or load a user-specified data file so that it is available for use.

label: Surface rendering
definitions: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.
A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.

label: Cysteine bridge detection
definitions: Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.

label: Free cysteine detection
definitions: Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.
A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.

label: Metal-bound cysteine detection
definitions: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.

label: Protein-metal contact calculation
definitions: Calculate protein residue contacts with metal in a structure.

label: Residue bump detection
definitions: Detect 'bumps' between residues in a structure, i.e. those with pairs of atoms whose Van der Waals' radii interpenetrate more than a defined distance.

label: Salt bridge calculation
definitions: Calculate (and possibly score) salt bridges in a protein structure.
Salt bridges are interactions between oppositely charged atoms in different residues. The output might include the inter-atomic distance.

label: Residue packing validation
definitions: Identify poorly packed residues in protein structures.

label: Protein geometry validation
definitions: Validate protein geometry, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc.

label: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment
definitions: Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.

label: siRNA duplex prediction
definitions: Identify or predict siRNA duplexes in RNA.

label: Sequence alignment refinement
definitions: Refine an existing sequence alignment.

label: Sequence file editing
definitions: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.

label: Representative sequence identification
definitions: Identify a representative sequence from a set of sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.

label: Statistical calculation
definitions: Perform a statistical data operation of some type, e.g. calibration or validation.

label: 3D-1D scoring matrix generation
definitions: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.
A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.

label: Transmembrane protein visualisation
definitions: Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.

label: Nucleic acid density plotting
definitions: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.

label: Sequence analysis
definitions: Analyse one or more known molecular sequences.

label: Sequence motif analysis
definitions: Analyse molecular sequence motifs.

label: Protein structure analysis
definitions: Analyse protein structural data.

label: Data handling
definitions: Basic (non-analytical) operations of some data, either a file or equivalent entity in memory, such that the same basic type of data is consumed as input and generated as output.

label: Protein function analysis
definitions: Analyse protein function, typically by processing protein sequence and/or structural data, and generate an informative report.

label: Protein folding analysis
definitions: Analyse, simulate or predict protein folding, typically by processing sequence and / or structural data.  For example, predict sites of nucleation or stabilisation key to protein folding.

label: Protein secondary structure analysis
definitions: Analyse protein secondary structure data.

label: Primer and probe design
definitions: Predict oligonucleotide primers or probes.

label: Database search
definitions: Search a database (or other data resource) with a supplied query and retrieve entries (or parts of entries) that are similar to the query.
Typically the query is compared to each entry and high scoring matches (hits) are returned. For example, a BLAST search of a sequence database.

label: Data retrieval
definitions: Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.

label: Prediction and recognition
definitions: Predict, recognise, detect or identify some properties of a biomolecule.

label: Comparison
definitions: Compare two or more things to identify similarities.

label: Optimisation and refinement
definitions: Refine or optimise some data model.

label: Modelling and simulation
definitions: Model or simulate some biological entity or system, typically using mathematical techniques including  dynamical systems, statistical models, differential equations, and game theoretic models.

label: Validation
definitions: Validate some data.

label: Mapping
definitions: Map properties to positions on an biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure), or assemble such an entity from constituent parts.

label: Design
definitions: Design a biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure) with specific properties.

label: Gene-set enrichment analysis
definitions: Analysis of a set of genes, corresponding e.g. to a gene expression profile, annotated with Gene Ontology (GO) concepts, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain GO concept within the studied set of genes is revealed.
The Gene Ontology (GO) is typically used, the input is a set of Gene IDs, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of GO concepts, each associated with a p-value.

label: RNA secondary structure analysis
definitions: Process (read and / or write) RNA secondary structure data.

label: RNA structure prediction
definitions: Predict RNA tertiary structure.

label: DNA structure prediction
definitions: Predict DNA tertiary structure.

label: Sequence comparison
definitions: Compare two or more molecular sequences.

label: Gene prediction
definitions: Detect, predict and identify genes or components of genes in DNA sequences, including promoters, coding regions, splice sites, etc.
Methods for gene prediction might be ab initio, based on phylogenetic comparisons, use motifs, sequence features, support vector machine, alignment etc.

label: Protein-protein interaction prediction
definitions: Identify or predict protein-protein interactions, interfaces, binding sites etc.

label: Protein architecture comparison
definitions: Compare the architecture of two or more protein structures.

label: Protein architecture recognition
definitions: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.

label: Molecular dynamics
definitions: Simulate molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.

label: Nucleic acid sequence analysis
definitions: Analyse a nucleic acid sequence (using methods that are only applicable to nucleic acid sequences).

label: Protein sequence analysis
definitions: Analyse a protein sequence (using methods that are only applicable to protein sequences).

label: Structure analysis
definitions: Analyse known molecular tertiary structures.

label: Nucleic acid structure analysis
definitions: Analyse nucleic acid tertiary structural data.

label: Structure comparison
definitions: Compare two or more molecular tertiary structures.

label: Helical wheel drawing
definitions: Render a helical wheel representation of protein secondary structure.

label: Topology diagram drawing
definitions: Render a topology diagram of protein secondary structure.

label: Protein structure comparison
definitions: Compare protein tertiary structures.
Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.

label: Protein secondary structure comparison
definitions: Compare protein secondary structures.

label: Protein subcellular localisation prediction
definitions: Predict the subcellular localisation of a protein sequence.
The prediction might include subcellular localisation (nuclear, cytoplasmic, mitochondrial, chloroplast, plastid, membrane etc) or export (extracellular proteins) of a protein.

label: Protein interaction prediction
definitions: Predict the interactions of proteins with other molecules.

label: Gene expression analysis
definitions: The application of bioinformatics methods to the study of gene products, typically by processing gene expression data or profiles, interpreting them in functional terms.

label: Pathway or network analysis
definitions: Generate, process or analyse a biological pathway or network.

label: Splicing model analysis
definitions: Analyse, characterize and model alternative splicing events, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.

label: DNA back-translation
definitions: Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.

label: Sequence generation (nucleic acid)
definitions: Generate a nucleic acid sequence by some means.

label: Sequence generation (protein)
definitions: Generate a protein sequence by some means.

label: Nucleic acid structure comparison
definitions: Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.

label: DNA mapping
definitions: Generate a map of a DNA sequence annotated with positional or non-positional features of some type.

label: Protein hydropathy calculation
definitions: Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein (from analysis of sequence or structural information).

label: Protein binding site prediction
definitions: Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.

label: Sequence tagged site (STS) mapping
definitions: Generate a physical DNA map (sequence map) from analysis of sequence tagged sites (STS).

An STS is a short subsequence of known sequence and location that occurs only once in the chromosome or genome that is being mapped. Sources of STSs include 1. expressed sequence tags (ESTs), simple sequence length polymorphisms (SSLPs), and random genomic sequences from cloned genomic DNA or database sequences.

label: Alignment
definitions: Compare two or more entities, typically the sequence or structure (or derivatives) of macromolecules, to identify equivalent subunits.

label: Protein fragment weight comparison
definitions: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.

label: Protein property comparison
definitions: Compare the physicochemical properties of two or more proteins (or reference data).

label: Clustering profile plotting
definitions: Visualise clustered quantitative data as set of different profiles, where each profile is plotted versus different entities or samples on the X-axis.

label: Proximity map plotting
definitions: Generate a plot of distances (distance or correlation matrix) between expression values.

label: Dendrogram visualisation
synonyms: Expression data tree or dendrogram rendering
definitions: Visualise clustered expression data using a tree diagram.

label: Principal component plotting
definitions: Visualize the results of a principal component analysis (orthogonal data transformation).

label: Scatter plot plotting
definitions: Render a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along two axes; the pattern of the points reveals any correlation.

label: Treemap visualisation
definitions: Visualise gene expression data after hierarchical clustering for representing hierarchical relationships.

label: Box-Whisker plot plotting
definitions: Generate a box plot, i.e. a depiction of groups of numerical data through their quartiles.

label: Physical mapping
definitions: Generate a physical (sequence) map of a DNA sequence showing the physical distance (base pairs) between features or landmarks such as restriction sites, cloned DNA fragments, genes and other genetic markers.

label: Analysis
definitions: Apply analytical methods to existing data of a specific type.
This excludes non-analytical methods that read and write the same basic type of data (for that, see 'Data handling').

label: Protein interaction analysis
definitions: Analyse known protein-protein, protein-DNA/RNA or protein-ligand interactions.

label: Residue distance calculation
definitions: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.

This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output.  It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.

label: Codon usage bias calculation
definitions: Calculate codon usage bias.

label: Codon usage bias plotting
definitions: Generate a codon usage bias plot.

label: Codon usage fraction calculation
definitions: Calculate the differences in codon usage fractions between two sequences, sets of sequences, codon usage tables etc.

label: Classification
definitions: Assign molecular sequences, structures or other biological data to a specific group or category according to qualities it shares with that group or category.

label: Sequence classification
definitions: Assign molecular sequence(s) to a group or category.

label: Structure classification
definitions: Assign molecular structure(s) to a group or category.

label: Protein comparison
definitions: Compare two or more proteins (or some aspect) to identify similarities.

label: Nucleic acid comparison
definitions: Compare two or more nucleic acids to identify similarities.

label: Structure editing
definitions: Edit, convert or otherwise change a  molecular tertiary structure, either randomly or specifically.

label: Sequence alignment editing
definitions: Edit, convert or otherwise change a molecular sequence alignment, either randomly or specifically.

label: Pathway or network visualisation
definitions: Render (visualise) a biological pathway or network.

label: Protein feature detection
definitions: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in proteins from analysing protein sequences or structures.

Features includes functional sites or regions, secondary structure, structural domains and so on. Methods might use fingerprints, motifs, profiles, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment etc to provide a mapping of a query protein sequence to a discriminatory element. This includes methods that search a secondary protein database (Prosite, Blocks, ProDom, Prints, Pfam etc.) to assign a protein sequence(s) to a known protein family or group.

label: Nucleic acid design
definitions: Design (or predict) nucleic acid sequences with specific chemical or physical properties.

label: Editing
definitions: Edit a data entity, either randomly or specifically.

label: Sequence assembly validation
definitions: Evaluate a DNA sequence assembly, typically for purposes of quality control.

label: Genome alignment
definitions: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.

label: Localised reassembly
definitions: Reconstruction of a sequence assembly in a localised area.

label: Sequence assembly visualisation
definitions: Render and visualise a DNA sequence assembly.

label: Base-calling
definitions: Identify base (nucleobase) sequence from a fluorescence 'trace' data generated by an automated DNA sequencer.

label: Bisulfite mapping
definitions: The mapping of methylation sites in a DNA (genome) sequence.

Bisulfite mapping follows high-throughput sequencing of DNA which has undergone bisulfite treatment followed by PCR amplification; unmethylated cytosines are specifically converted to thymine, allowing the methylation status of cytosine in the DNA to be detected.

label: Sequence contamination filtering
definitions: Identify and filter a (typically large) sequence data set to remove sequences from contaminants in the sample that was sequenced.

label: Sequence trimming
definitions: Cut (remove) the end from a molecular sequence.

This includes

ennd trimming
Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove misleading ends.
For example trim polyA tails, introns and primer sequence flanking the sequence of amplified exons, or other unwanted sequence.

trimming to a reference sequence, 
Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove the sequence ends that extend beyond an assembled reference sequence.

vector trimming
Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove sequence-specific end regions, typically contamination from vector sequences.

label: Genome feature comparison
definitions: Compare the features of two genome sequences.
Genomic elements that might be compared include genes, indels, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), retrotransposons, tandem repeats and so on.

label: Sequencing error detection
definitions: Detect errors in DNA sequences generated from sequencing projects).

label: Genotyping
definitions: Analyse DNA sequence data to identify differences between the genetic composition (genotype) of an individual compared to other individual's or a reference sequence.

Methods might consider cytogenetic analyses, copy number polymorphism (and calculate copy number calls for copy-number variation(CNV) regions), single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), , rare copy number variation (CNV) identification, loss of heterozygosity data and so on.

label: Genetic variation analysis
definitions: Analyse a genetic variation, for example to annotate its location, alleles, classification, and effects on individual transcripts predicted for a gene model.

Genetic variation annotation provides contextual interpretation of coding SNP consequences in transcripts. It allows comparisons to be made between variation data in different populations or strains for the same transcript.

label: Read mapping
definitions: Align short oligonucleotide sequences (reads) to a larger (genomic) sequence.

The purpose of read mapping is to identify the location of sequenced fragments within a reference genome and assumes that there is, in fact, at least local similarity between the fragment and reference sequences.

label: Split read mapping
definitions: A varient of oligonucleotide mapping where a read is mapped to two separate locations because of possible structural variation.

label: Community profiling
definitions: Analyse DNA sequences in order to identify a DNA 'barcode'; marker genes or any short fragment(s) of DNA that are useful to diagnose the taxa of biological organisms.

label: Polymorphism detection
definitions: Detect mutations in multiple DNA sequences, for example, from the alignment and comparison of the fluorescent traces produced by DNA sequencing hardware.

label: Chromatogram visualisation
definitions: Visualise, format or render an image of a Chromatogram.

label: Methylation analysis
definitions: Determine cytosine methylation states in nucleic acid sequences.

label: Whole genome methylation analysis
definitions: Measure the overall level of methyl cytosines in a genome from analysis of experimental data, typically from chromatographic methods and methyl accepting capacity assay.

label: Gene methylation analysis
definitions: Analysing the DNA methylation of specific genes or regions of interest.

label: Genome visualisation
definitions: Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.

label: Genome comparison
definitions: Compare the sequence or features of two or more genomes, for example, to find matching regions.

label: Genome indexing
definitions: Generate an index of a genome sequence.

Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment.  The Burrows-Wheeler Transform (BWT) is a permutation of the genome based on a suffix array algorithm.  A suffix array consists of the lexicographically sorted list of suffixes of a genome.

label: Spectral analysis
definitions: Analyse one or more spectra from mass spectrometry (or other) experiments.

label: Peak detection
definitions: Identify peaks in a spectrum from a mass spectrometry, NMR, or some other spectrum-generating experiment.

label: Scaffolding
definitions: Link together a non-contiguous series of genomic sequences into a scaffold, consisting of sequences separated by gaps of known length.  The sequences that are linked are typically typically contigs; contiguous sequences corresponding to read overlaps.
Scaffold may be positioned along a chromosome physical map to create a "golden path".

label: Scaffold gap completion
definitions: Fill the gaps in a sequence assembly (scaffold) by merging in additional sequences.

Different techniques are used to generate gap sequences to connect contigs, depending on the size of the gap. For small (5-20kb) gaps, PCR amplification and sequencing is used.  For large (>20kb) gaps, fragments are cloned (e.g. in BAC (Bacterial artificial chromosomes) vectors) and then sequenced.

label: Sequencing quality control
definitions: Raw sequence data quality control.
Analyse raw sequence data from a sequencing pipeline and identify (and possiby fix) problems.

label: Read pre-processing
definitions: Pre-process sequence reads to ensure (or improve) quality and reliability.

For example process paired end reads to trim low quality ends remove short sequences, identify sequence inserts, detect chimeric reads, or remove low quality sequnces including vector, adaptor, low complexity and contaminant sequences. Sequences might come from genomic DNA library, EST libraries, SSH library and so on.

label: Species frequency estimation
definitions: Estimate the frequencies of different species from analysis of the molecular sequences, typically of DNA recovered from environmental samples.

label: Peak calling
definitions: Identify putative protein-binding regions in a genome sequence from analysis of Chip-sequencing data or ChIP-on-chip data.

Chip-sequencing combines chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with massively parallel DNA sequencing to generate a set of reads, which are aligned to a genome sequence.  The enriched areas contain the binding sites of DNA-associated proteins.  For example, a transcription factor binding site. ChIP-on-chip in contrast combines chromatin immunoprecipitation ('ChIP') with microarray ('chip').  "Peak-pair calling" is similar to "Peak calling" in the context of ChIP-exo.

label: Differential gene expression analysis
definitions: Identify from molecular sequence analysis (typically from analysis of microarray or RNA-seq data) genes whose expression levels are significantly different between two sample groups.

Differential gene expression analysis is used, for example, to identify which genes are up-regulated (increased expression) or down-regulated (decreased expression) between a group treated with a drug and a control groups.

label: Gene set testing
definitions: Analyse gene expression patterns (typically from DNA microarray datasets) to identify sets of genes that are associated with a specific trait, condition, clinical outcome etc.
Gene sets can be defined beforehand by biological function, chromosome locations and so on.

label: Variant classification
definitions: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.

Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)

label: Variant prioritisation
definitions: Identify biologically interesting variants by prioritizing individual variants, for example, homozygous variants absent in control genomes.

Variant prioritisation can be used for example to produce a list of variants responsible for 'knocking out' genes in specific genomes. Methods amino acid substitution, aggregative approaches, probabilistic approach, inheritance and unified likelihood-frameworks.

label: Variant calling
definitions: Identify and map genomic alterations, including single nucleotide polymorphisms, short indels and structural variants, in a genome sequence.
Somatic variant calling is the detection of variations established in somatic cells and hence not inherited as a germ line variant.
Variant detection
Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.

label: Structural variation detection
definitions: Detect large regions in a genome subject to copy-number variation, or other structural variations in genome(s).

Methods might involve analysis of whole-genome array comparative genome hybridisation or single-nucleotide polymorphism arrays, paired-end mapping of sequencing data, or from analysis of short reads from new sequencing technologies.

label: Exome assembly
definitions: Analyse sequencing data from experiments aiming to selectively sequence the coding regions of the genome.

label: Read depth analysis
definitions: Analyse mapping density (read depth) of (typically) short reads from sequencing platforms, for example, to detect deletions and duplications.

label: Gene expression QTL analysis
synonyms: Gene expression quantitative trait loci profiling
definitions: Combine classical quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis with gene expression profiling, for example, to describe describe cis- and trans-controlling elements for the expression of phenotype associated genes.

label: Copy number estimation
definitions: Estimate the number of copies of loci of particular gene(s) in DNA sequences typically from gene-expression profiling technology based on microarray hybridisation-based experiments. For example, estimate copy number (or marker dosage) of a dominant marker in samples from polyploid plant cells or tissues, or chromosomal gains and losses in tumors.

Methods typically implement some statistical model for hypothesis testing, and methods estimate total copy number, i.e. do not distinguish the two inherited chromosomes quantities (specific copy number).

label: Primer removal
definitions: Remove forward and/or reverse primers from nucleic acid sequences (typically PCR products).

label: Transcriptome assembly
definitions: Infer a transcriptome sequence by analysis of short sequence reads.

label: Sequence coordinate conversion
definitions: Convert one set of sequence coordinates to another, e.g. convert coordinates of one assembly to another, cDNA to genomic, CDS to genomic, protein translation to genomic etc.

label: Document similarity calculation
definitions: Calculate similarity between 2 or more documents.

label: Document clustering
definitions: Cluster (group) documents on the basis of their calculated similarity.

label: Named-entity and concept recognition
definitions: Recognise named entities, ontology concepts, tags, events, and dictionary terms within documents.

label: ID mapping
definitions: Map data identifiers to one another for example to establish a link between two biological databases for the purposes of data integration.
The mapping can be achieved by comparing identifier values or some other means, e.g. exact matches to a provided sequence.

label: Anonymisation
definitions: Process data in such a way that makes it hard to trace to the person which the data concerns.

label: Sequence checksum generation
definitions: Generate a checksum of a molecular sequence.

label: Bibliography generation
definitions: Construct a bibliography from the scientific literature.

label: Protein quaternary structure prediction
definitions: Predict the structure of a multi-subunit protein and particularly how the subunits fit together.

label: Molecular surface analysis
definitions: Analyse the surface properties of proteins or other macromolecules, including surface accessible pockets, interior inaccessible cavities etc.

label: Ontology comparison
definitions: Compare two or more ontologies, e.g. identify differences.

label: Format detection
definitions: Recognition of which format the given data is in.

'Format recognition' is not a bioinformatics-specific operation, but of great relevance in bioinformatics. Should be removed from EDAM if/when captured satisfactorily in a suitable domain-generic ontology.

label: Splitting
definitions: Split a file containing multiple data items into many files, each containing one item

label: Generation
definitions: Construct some data entity.
For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.

label: Deposition
definitions: Deposit some data in a database or some other type of repository or software system.
For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.

label: Clustering
